Trustee named to sit on MSJC budget committee

June 28th, 2008

FYI/Blog

At the June 26, 2008 board meeting, during discussion of the tentative budget, Trustee Kadow asked to sit on the college budget committee and by general board consensus the request was affirmed without further discussion and no comment from the new S/P. The matter was not on the agenda.

MSJC BP 2220 /Committees of the Board

“The Board may by action establish committees that it determines are necessary to assist the Board in its responsibilities. Any committee established by Board action shall comply with the requirements of the Brown Act and policies regarding open meetings.”

“Board committees have no authority or power to act on behalf of the Board. Findings or recommendations shall be reported to the Board for consideration.”

Board members sitting on a college committees do not meet the definition or intent of this BP. Board members having potential for influence and/or micromanagement without established parameters of authority could be intimidating.

In this case, the boundaries of authority appear rather “gray”.

Valley school responds to grand jury report/ValleyChronicle

June 20th, 2008

http://www.thevalleychronicle.com/articles/2008/06/20/news/04nacademy.txt

FYI

“Among the major allegations in the grand jury report were that a member of the charter school board used business credit cards from a nonprofit agency he works for to pay for school activities.”

“The unsigned response also accuses the grand jury of doing a poor job of investigating allegations and harming the reputation of the school needlessly as a result.”

Blog:

MSJC’s newly appointed Superintendent/President, is a member of this board and Mr. Duistermars, has been a past MSJC graduation speaker. Where is accountability with an “unsigned” response? Where was the school attorney…..gone?

MSJC president to start Monday

June 14th, 2008

http://www.pe.com/localnews/temecula/stories/PE_News_Local_S_contract14.40512eb.html#

“Roger Schultz, who most recently served as the college’s VP of Student Services, will start as superintendent/president on Monday. Trustees approved his contract Thursday in San Jacinto. Schultz, who has been with the college since 2001, will earn $190,800 a year.”

Blog:

Four of the five newly appointed administrative personnel were filled by in-house candidates. MSJC has had a history of turn-over in administration.

MSJC Police

June 10th, 2008

http://www.msjc.edu/apps/pubs.asp?Q=1&T=About+the+Police+Department&P=64

FYI/MSJC website

About the MSJC Police Department

Mt. San Jacinto College employs P.O.S.T. certified police officers whose peace officer authority extends throughout California. The members of Mt. San Jacinto College Police Department are responsible for protecting life and property on or near any property owned or controlled by Mt. San Jacinto Community College District.

Blog:

Websters College Dictionary

“near” - within, or a short distance; close in space; close in time; being close by; not distant; close to in condition or state; in the immediate vicinity;

A reasonable interpretation of “near” would seem to be within a 1-2 mile radius of the campus(es).

(3 votes, average: 5 out of 5)

California Education Code Section 72330/College Police

June 9th, 2008

http://law.onecle.com/california/education/72330.html

MSJC BP 7610/College Police - Approved/Revised by BOT 9/13/07

“The Board has established a police department under the supervision of one Chief(s) of Police, who shall report directly to the Chief Human Resources Officer. The department(s) shall have jurisdiction to enforce the law on or near the campus(es) and other grounds or properties owned, operated, controlled or administered by the District.”

Blog:

Both Ed Code and board policy state the intent/purpose of an established cc police department. How one interprets “near the campus(es)” determines whether the PD covers a few blocks “nearby the campus(es)” as the law reads or the sphere of Menifee which is over broad in interpretation of the code. The Board of Trustees have not addressed the issue in any policy discussion. They should.
